snippet: The control of light is the core of the photographer Harold Ross's work. Mr. Ross, who has been "painting with light" for more than 20 years, pairs undeniably real scenes with the artificiality of lighting.
abstract: The control of light is the core of the photographer Harold Ross's work. Mr. Ross, who has been "painting with light" for more than 20 years, pairs undeniably real scenes with the artificiality of lighting.

byline.original: By FRED R. CONRAD and KERRI MACDONALD

lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, the fine art photographer Harold Ross has been making images using a technique known as "painting with light," which involves casting light on and around subjects in the dark during a time exposure. Mr. Ross, who also does commercial and studio photography, prefers to call the process "sculpting with light." Using a Phase One Back on a Hassleblad for still life photographs and a Cambo Wide RS for landscapes, he spends hours creating his images, which look like oil paintings, rich in color and depth.
